angles.name: High Angle
angles.description: The camera is positioned above the subject, looking down. This angle can make the subject appear smaller, weaker, or more vulnerable.

angles.name: Low Angle
angles.description: The camera is placed below the subject, looking up. This can make the subject look more powerful or threatening.

angles.name: Eye Level
angles.description: The camera is positioned at the subject's eye level. This is a neutral angle, often used for conversations or to show characters on an equal footing.

angles.name: Bird's Eye View
angles.description: The camera is placed very high above the subject, offering a panoramic view of the landscape or setting. This can provide context or show the subject's insignificance in the larger environment.

angles.name: Worm's Eye View
angles.description: An extreme version of the low angle shot, where the camera is placed as if on the ground, looking up. This can create a sense of grandeur or awe.

angles.name: Dutch Angle
angles.description: The camera is tilted, so the horizon line is not level. This technique is used to create a sense of unease, tension, or disorientation.

angles.name: Over-the-Shoulder Shot
angles.description: The camera looks over the shoulder of one character, focusing on another character or object. This is often used in conversations to create a sense of inclusion.

angles.name: Point-of-View Shot (POV)
angles.description: The camera shows what a character is looking at, effectively putting the audience in the character's shoes. This can create a strong connection to the character's experiences.

angles.name: Two-Shot
angles.description: A shot that frames two characters, often used in conversations to show the interaction between them.

angles.name: Three-Shot
angles.description: Similar to the two-shot but includes three characters. This is used for group interactions.

angles.name: Extreme Close-Up
angles.description: The camera is very close to the subject, showing detail that would not be visible in a wider shot. This can highlight emotions or important objects.

angles.name: Close-Up
angles.description: The camera is close to the subject, usually framing the face. This is used to capture expressions and emotions.

angles.name: Medium Shot
angles.description: The camera frames the subject from the waist up. This is a common shot for dialogue scenes, offering a balance between the character and their setting.

angles.name: Long Shot
angles.description: The subject is framed from a greater distance, showing them in their entirety. This can establish the setting or the character's place in it.

angles.name: Extreme Long Shot
angles.description: The camera is at a very long distance from the subject, often used to show vast landscapes or settings, making the subject appear small or insignificant.

angles.name: Master Shot
angles.description: A shot that covers the characters and action in one continuous scene, usually from a long or full shot perspective. This is often used at the beginning of a scene to establish setting and relationships.

angles.name: Crane Shot
angles.description: The camera moves vertically, typically with the use of a crane, to reveal the subject or landscape. This can add drama or reveal something previously unseen.

angles.name: Tracking Shot
angles.description: The camera moves along with the subject, keeping them in frame while they move through their environment. This can be used to follow a character or explore a space.

angles.name: Steadicam Shot
angles.description: A shot achieved using a Steadicam for smooth movement while following action or moving through a location. This allows for fluid motion without the constraints of tracks.
